intro: Phlegmariurus marsupiiformis, commonly known as the marsh holly, is a species of liverwort belonging to the family Porellaceae. It is characterized by its erect, branching growth form and is typically found in moist, shaded environments such as forest floors and wetlands. The plant has a thalloid structure with a distinct central axis and leaf-like structures called phyllodes. It reproduces through spores released from specialized structures called sporophytes, which are borne on the upper surfaces of the stems. This liverwort plays a role in soil stabilization and provides habitat for microorganisms in its native ecosystems.
